summary.seg: Offering a clear exposition of Christian salvation, the Speculum humanae salvationis, composed by an anonymous author, possibly a Dominican, was a valuable aid for preachers. Over 400 manuscript copies have survived, two-fifths with lengthy cycles of pictures. In most chapters, an episode from the life of Christ of the Virgin Mary is juxtaposed with events drawn from the Old Testament or other sources, an interpretive method known as typology.

The illustrations are typically arranged in groups of four, with two per page set above columns of explanatory text. This example, with forty-two chapters and 170 pictures, adheres to the standard format. Certain compositions are based on models created in Utrecht workshops, which suggests that the manuscript was produced in the region. Every scene, apart from a single drawing of a candelabrum that is tinted in brownish orange (15r), is rendered in grisaille, a technique favoured by illustrators working in the Northern Netherlands in the second and third quarter of the fifteenth century.

At first impression, the pale grey modelling looks as if it had been done with a broad lead point or crayon, but it is more likely to have been painted with a dilute solution of carbon black or iron-gall ink. Unlike grisaille in the French tradition of Jean Pucelle, this Dutch grisaille does not show any stippling or 'pointillist' technique.
Dr Deirdre Jackson, Assistant Curator of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts, The Morgan Library & Museum
Prof. Nigel Morgan, Emeritus Professor, Department of History of Art, University of Cambridge

foliation.note: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

collation.signatures: No quire signatures. (Modern quire signatures written in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the recto of the first leaf of each quire).

supportDesc.condition: Some water-staining along the fore-edge and outer corners of the leaves, sometimes impinging upon but not affecting the legibility of the text.

additions.note: References to the Bible written in red ink in the margins of the Prohemium (ff. 3v-4v).

binding.p: Original binding (Binski/Zutshi) or 16th-century (Ringrose), sewn on five bands: brown calf (re-backed) over wooden boards, with blind-tooling on the front and rear covers, as follows: a double frame formed by triple fillets; the inner frame mitred to form a central compartment containing a panel stamp of a lion and griffin supporting an imperial crown and shield of a double-headed eagle displayed, within a border of heraldic animals (dog, dragon, griffin, eagles, stag, unicorn, with shields at the four corners: three fleur-de-lys, eagle displayed, three mill rinds, and lion rampant; four-sided frame with scenes of brazen serpent, Crucifixion and Resurrection; two panels with heraldic roses and foliage at head and tail; two pairs of holes at the fore-edge from clasps, now lost.

history.origin:
Mid-/third quarter of the 15th century (Binski and Zutshi) or second half of the 15th century (Ringrose). Northern Netherlands, perhaps Utrecht.
According to the description of the manuscript in B. Cardon, Manuscripts of the Speculum humanae salvacionis in the Southern Netherlands (c. 1410-1470) (Leuven: Peeters, 1996), pp. 382-84, 'the models used [for the miniatures] were related to the ones in workshops in Utrecht in the mid-15th century, drawing upon Eyckian sources'.

provenance.p: Perhaps the Abbey of St Bavo, Ghent. Cardon, pp. 382-84
Perhaps in Utrecht in the 16th century: '21 [St W?] traiecti in edibus Decani S. Marie' (inscription on front pastedown).

Jean-Baptiste-Godefroid Delbecq (1771-1840) Delbecq, Jean-Baptiste-Godefroid 1771-1840 , Ghent schoolteacher and collector of prints and books: his sale, de Porre and Verhulst, Ghent, 8-12 September 1840, lot 49. According to the note by J.L.C. Jacob Jacob, J.L.C., 1805-1865 (see below), Delbecq had purchased the manuscript at the time when the monasteries in Ghent were closed.
J.L.C. Jacob (1805-1865) Jacob, J.L.C., 1805-1865 , bookseller: purchased at the sale of Jean-Baptiste Delbecq (notes concerning the manuscript, f. ii).

Sir Thomas Brooke (1830-1908) Brooke, Thomas, Sir, 1830-1908 , wool merchant and book collector, Armitage Bridge House, Yorkshire: his bookplate (and ?shelfmark 'A.37') ([iv] recto, and recorded in the catalogue of his collection, published 1891 (vol. 2, p. 604).

p.name: Sir John Arthur Brooke (d. 1920) Brooke, John Arthur, 1844-1920: his sale, Sotheby's, 25 and 30 May 1921, lot 1350.

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library by John Charrington (1856-1939) Charrington, John, 1856-1939 , First Honorary Keeper of Prints, Fitzwilliam Museum (1909-1939) (donation bookplate, front pastedown).

recordHist.source: The prose introduction is taken from the entry for Add. 6447 in the exhibition catalogue, 'Colour: The Art and Science of Illuminated Manuscripts' (2016), by kind permission of the authors. The catalogue entry draws on the descriptions provided by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011) (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press) and Jayne Ringrose, Summary catalogue of the Additional medieval manuscripts in Cambridge University Library acquired before 1940 (Woodbridge: Boydell Press, 2009, as well as an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1947 and 1970 by H.L. Pink Pink, H. L. , now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/75) and available online via Apollo.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.author: Justinian
msItem.title: Digest
msItem.explicit: restitui, totum viro fideicommissum dotis deberi
msItem.note: Begins imperfectly in Book 31, Chapter 76, prologue; ends imperfectly in Book 31, Chapter 77, section 2.

msItem.author: Justinian
msItem.title: Digest
msItem.incipit: scripture non impedit causam iuris ac voluntatis
msItem.explicit: derogare iuri testamentum fieri prohibendo voluit. Rogo, filia
msItem.note: Begins imperfectly in Book 31, Chapter 77, section 12; ends imperfectly in Book 31, Chapter 77, section 25.

extent.seg: Fragment, comprising two originally contiguous leaves, now preserved as pastedowns. Between the end of the text on the front pastedown, and the beginning of the text on the rear pastedown, one page of text is obscured. It is not possible to determine whether the recto or verso side of each leaf is visible.

layout.seg: Two columns, 50 lines, frame and line ruling, in leadpoint but mostly not visible, written below top line.
Gloss ruled separately, frame and line ruling, in leadpoint.

handDesc.handNote: Written in an Italian littera textualis.

additions.p: A few interlinear and intercolumnar glosses and annotations.

msItem.title: De reparatione lapsi
msItem.author: John Chrysostom
msItem.rubric: 1r: Incipit liber beati iohannis crisostimi de reparacione lapsi
msItem.incipit: 1r: Quis dabit capiti meo aquam, et oculis meis fontem lacrimarum
msItem.explicit: 1v: quantumcunque sit salutis desiderium, quamtumuis sit grande saluandi propositum
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly. Text printed from Monte Cassino MS CLII in Florilegium Casinense; text here ends on p. 391, col. 2, l. 21.

listBibl.bibl: Florilegium Casinense (Montecassino, 1873-94), III, Bibliotheca Casinensis, pp. 389-411

msItem.title: Speculum humanae saluacionis (waste leaf)
msItem.incipit: 2v: Quoniam modum nostre redempcionis scire desideramus / Primo de annunciacione beate marie incipiamus
msItem.explicit: 2v: Hec litteralis huius visionis interpretacio / Est alia mistica prefiguracio
msItem.note:
Folio 2 is a waste leaf, the verso containing two drawings and columns of text, as per the rest of the manuscript:
col. 1: Annunciation to St Anne (mismatch with the text, which concerns the Annunciation to the Virgin Mary).
col. 2: King Astyages' dream (a bearded figure shown beside his bed, instead of Astyages' daughter; see comparable illustration on 7v, where it accompanies the meeting of Joachim and Anna). These faults may account for the cancellation of this leaf. The text is repeated, with slight variation, in its proper place on f. 7v.

msItem.title: Parabola
msItem.incipit: 3r: Ad iusticiam qui erudiunt / Fulgebunt tanquam stelle eternitatis
msItem.explicit: 3r: O bone ihesu da ut hoc opusculum tibi complaceat / Ut proximos edificet et gratos tibi faciat

msItem.title: Prohemium
msItem.rubric: 3v: Hic incipit prohemium cuiusdam noue compilacionis cuius titulus est speculum humane saluacionis
msItem.incipit: 3v: Expediens et utile videtur quod in hoc prohemio exponatur / De quibus materiis et historiis in capitulo quolibet dicatur
msItem.explicit: 4v: Tercia figura potest accipi in conuiuiis filiorum iob / Quia nullum inuenimus tam continua conuiuia fecisse et tot
msItem.note: Prohemium unprinted in Lutz and Perdrizet edition, but appears in full on ff. 4v-5v of Speculum humanae salvationis, vollstÃ¤ndige Faksimilie-Ausgabe des Codex Cremifanensis 243 des Benediktinerstifts KremsmÃ¼nster, ed. by W. NeumÃ¼ller (Graz: Akadem. Druck- u. Verlagsanst.

msItem.title: Text
msItem.incipit: 5v: In quo habetur hominis casus et modus reparacionis / In hoc speculo potest homo considerare
msItem.explicit: 47r: O bone ihesu proptertuam benignissimam bonitatem / Per duc nos ad illam perpetuam iocunditatem. Amen.
msItem.note: Lacks the sections on the Seven Stations of the Passion, the Seven Sorrows and Seven Joys of the Virgin, which follow ch. 42. For the deletion of these three chapters, see: Adrian Wilson and Joyce Lancaster Wilson, A medieval mirror: Speculum humanae salvationis 1324-1500 (Berkeley; London: University of California Press, 1984), p. 28.

120-125 180

handNote.p: Written in two hybrida hands: 1r-1v and 2v-47r.

decoNote.p:
170 drawings in grisaille, two per page, each occupying the upper half of a text column; outlined in ink or pencil, shaded with black chalk or lead; depicting biblical and historical scenes. The drawings follow the usual set found with the text, classified by E. Breitenbach, Speculum humanae salvationis: eine typengeschichtliche Untersuchung, Studien der deutschen Kunstgeschichte 272 (Strassburg: J.H.E. Heitz, 1930) in his IV Kreis (p. 74) as being of Western origin, and says of it (p. 75) 'steht innerhalb der Kreises isoliert' (i.e. 'stands alone within that circle'). According to the description by B. Cardon, Manuscripts of the Speculum humanae salvacionis in the Southern Netherlands (c. 1410-1470) (Leuven: Peeters, 1996), pp. 382-84, 'the models used were related to the ones in workshops in Utrecht in the mid-15th century, drawing upon Eyckian sources'.
2v: Annunciation to St Anne; King Astyages' dream, with bearded king holding branches with leaves
5v: Fall of Lucifer; Creation of Eve
6r: God instructing Adam and Eve; Temptation of Eve
6v: Fall: Adam eating and Eve taking the fruit; Expulsion of Adam and Eve
7r: Eve spinning and Adam digging; dove bringing olive branch to Noah's Ark
7v: Joachim and Anna at Golden Gate; King Astyages' dream with his daughter
8r: Hortus conclusus and fons signatus ; Barlaam's prophecy
8v: Nativity of the Virgin; Tree of Jesse
9r: Porta clausa ; Temple of Solomon
9v: Presentation of the Virgin in the Temple; Mensa Solis
10r: sacrifice of Yepte's daughter; Queen of Persia observing her domain
10v: wedding of Mary and Joseph; wedding of Sara, Raguel's daughter, and Tobias
11r: turris barris ; tower hung with a thousand shields
11v: Annunciation; God appearing to Moses in burning bush and giving him Tablets
12r: Gideon's fleece; Rebecca giving water to Eleazar
12v: Nativity; vision of Pharaoh's butler
13r: Aaron's rod; Emperor Octavian consulting Sibyl who receives vision of the Virgin and Child inside the sun
13v: Adoration of the Magi; Magi pointing at star
14r: three strong men bringing water from Bethlehem to David; servant bringing chalice to Solomon
14v: Presentation in the Temple; Ark of the Covenant
15r: candlestick with seven lamps (menorah); Presentation of Samuel in the Temple
15v: idols falling off columns as Holy Family enters Egypt; sculpture of the Virgin and Child made by Egyptians
16r: Moses breaking Pharaoh's crown; Nebuchadnezzar's vision of a statue
16v: Baptism of Christ, witnessed by an angel; Brazen Sea
17r: leper Naaman bathing in Jordan; two men carrying Ark across dry river Jordan
17v: Temptation of Christ, with Satan and three dice; Daniel breaking idol Bel and killing dragon
18r: David defeating Goliath; David killing bear and lion
18v: Mary Magdalene drying Christ's feet with her hair; Manasseh pentitent in captivity
19r: return of the Prodigal son; David repenting before Nathan
19v: Christ's entry into Jerusalem; Jeremiah lamenting before gates of Jerusalem
20r: David greeted after his triumph and bearing the head of Goliath; Heliodorus punished by two angels for attempting to plunder the Temple
20v: Last Supper; God giving manna to people of Israel
21r: Lamb, symbolising Christ ('Agnus Dei'); Melchisedech offering bread and wine to Abraham
21v: Christ prostrating his enemies with one word; Samson killing a thousand men with a donkey's jaw
22r: Shamgar killing six hundred men; David killing eight hundred men
22v: Betrayal of Christ; Joab killing Amasa
23r: Saul threatening David; Cain killing Abel
23v: Mocking of Christ; torture of Hur
24r: Noah ridiculed by Cham; blinded Samson ridiculed by Philistines
24v: Flagellation; Achior tied to tree by Holofernes' servants
25r: Lamech berated by his wives; Job attacked by Satan and by his wife
25v: Christ crowned with Crown of Thorns and mocked; Darius's concubine Apamene placing crown on her head
26r: Shimei threatening David with stone and club; King Amon threatening David's messengers
26v: Carrying of the Cross; Isaac carrying wood to the altar
27r: son of vineyard owner cast out and killed (Parable of the Wicked Husbandmen); two men carrying vine from Promised Land to desert
27v: Christ nailed to the Cross; Tubalchain with hammer and Jubal with psaltery
28r: Isaiah's martyrdom; King Moab sacrificing his son
28v: Crucifixion; Nebuchadnezzar's vision of tree
29r: King Codrus sacrificing his life for liberation of his citizens; Eleazar killing elephant
29v: Longinus piercing Christ's side and Jews mocking him; David ridiculed by Michol
30r: Absalom's death; King Embmedorach cutting his father's body in three hundred pieces and feeding vultures
30v: Deposition; Joseph's brothers with his tunic
31r: Adam and Eve lamenting Abel's death; Naomi asking her daughters-in-law to call here 'Mara' (i.e. bitter) because of her misfortune
31v: Entombment of Christ; two men carrying bier with Abner's coffin
32r: Joseph in well addressed by two of his brothers; Jonah cast into the sea
32v: Hellmouth with four levels; angel cooling three youths in fiery furnace
33r: angel sending Habakkuk to feed Daniel's in lion's den; bird using worm's blood to free young one from glass cover
33v: Christ's triumph over Satan; Benaiah killing lion
34r: Samson killing lion with his bare hands; Ehud piercing Eglon with his sword
34v: Virgin surrounded by Instruments of the Pasion and triumphing over Satan; Judith beheading Holofernes
35r: Jael piercing Cysara's eye with sword; Queen Tomyris beheading Cyrus
35v: saints rescued from Hell (shown as Hellmouth) by Christ; people of Israel set free from Egypt by angel
36r: Abraham rescued from Chaldaeans' fire by God; angel leading Lot and his family out of Sodom
36v: Resurrection: Christ stepping out of the tomb; Samson removing gates of Gaza
37r: Jonah emerging from whale; builders of Solomon's Temple with corner stone
37v: Ascension of Christ; Jacob's dream of heavenly ladder
38r: Christ bringing back lost sheep; Elijah in fiery chariot
38v: Pentecost; Tower of Babel
39r: God giving Moses Tablets; Elisha filling poor widow's vessels with oil
39v: Virgin praying surrounded by Instruments of the Passion and manger with ox and ass; Anna, Tobias's wife, troubled by her son's absence
40r: woman looking for her drachma (Parable of the Lost Coin/Piece of Silver); Saul giving Michal to Phalathiel/Palti
40v: Coronation of the Virgin; David playing harp before Ark
41r: St John's vision of woman surrounded by sun and standing on moon; Solomon's mother, Bathsheba, seated on his right side
41v: Virgin interceding for the sinners; Abigail pleading to David to have pity on Nabal
42r: Thecuites reconciling David and Absalom; wise woman showing Sheba's head to Joab
42v: Virgin protecting sinners under her cloak; Tharbis saving city of Saba from Moses' siege by asking her father to let her marry Moses
43r: woman of Thebes drops millstone on Abimelech; Michal speaking to soldier while David escapes through window
43v: Christ displaying wounds before God; Antipater showing wounds to Julius Caesar
44r: Virgin showing her breasts ('Maria mediatrix'); Esther pleading to Ahasuerus for people of Israel
44v: Last Judgement: Christ seated on rainbow, with feet resting on orb, lily and sword at his head, flanked by two angels with trumpets above dead rising from graves; three men bringing gifts to nobleman seated under canopy
45r: five wise and five foolish virgins (Parable of the Ten Virgins); God's hand writing on the wall before King Balthazar 'Mane tetel fares'
45v: devils punishing sinful souls in cauldron; two men cutting David's enemies with saw
46r: Gideon riding and dragging enemy; Pharaoh and his army drowned in Red Sea
46v: God holding the crucifix ('Throne of Mercy'); Queen of Sheba before Solomon
47r: feast of King Ahasuerus; Job's sons feasting
Four- to eight-line initials in blue, with internal void decoration, and infill and marginal flourishing in red ink (ff. 1r, 2v, 5v).
Two- or three-line initials, alternating in red or blue, occasionally with internal void decoration.
Headings written and paraph marks drawn in red; litterae notabiliores touched in red.
